dialogues.text: (gently) It's all right. It's over. It's all over now...

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: But it wasn't. Not by a long shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman stands at the counter, the New York Times in fron him, spritzing a cappuccino a portable phone tucked to hi ear... MUSIC on the radio...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Lisa, darling, it's Dad...how's it going...? What? I can't hear you.  42 43 40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns down his radio -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, at her cluttered desk, filled with paperwork. She's attractive, with her mother's important hair but without Iris' aura of authority. Lisa is always overwhelmed. And just now upset as well, curt...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I said I'm fine. INTERCUT WITH a puzzled COLEMAN -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You don't sound fine. (no reply) How's the class coming? (smiles) What happened to the little kid who couldn't recognize the letter N? Did he ever get it? Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (frowns) Would you care to know how I am?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I know how you are.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (vague premonition) Do you? She's staring into space, passing a hand over her forehea

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sweetheart, what's the matter? You sound -

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Dad, Marky told me all about it!

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Told you all about what?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Dad, everyone in Athena knows-~-  43 44 41.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (his anger rising) Who? Who is everyone? The line goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lisa? Lisa...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: A NEATLY FOLDED PIECE OF TYPING PAPER--written in block letters with a red ball point pen we read: "EVERYON

dialogues.speaker: NELSON .PRIMUS'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Everyone knows you're exploiting an abused illiterate woman half your age. REVERSE ON NELSON PRIMUS, Coleman's attorney, an amiable fellow in his thirties; he wears a suit that hints of Ral Lauren more than Brooks Brothers. Nelson rapidly rereads letter, mumbling the words together-

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: "Evéryone knows you're exploiting an abused illiterate woman half your age." A grim smile as he sets aside the letter and looks O.S.:

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, if this doesn't take the cake- CROSS-CUT TO COLEMAN--pacing back and forth in front of h attorney's desk.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: That's not all; my kids have even got wind of it.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You don't say...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: What's more, I know damn well who wrote this - Delphine Roux.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Professor of Languages and Literature. (irate) I hired her for Christ's sake! I hired all of them..!

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Why would she send you something like this?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I've no idea. How should I know? You're my lawyer. I want you to send her a letter and warn her off.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: She'll just deny she ever -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: That's her writing! Any handwriting expert would con-

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: You're being hasty -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: No! No I'm not -

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Yes you are, same as when you resigned from the college, just as the whole "Spooks" thing was on the point of blowing over. I told you then -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: And I told you: they killed my wife! What else could I-?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Coleman. Slow down. SIT. Reluctantly, Coleman obeys. Nelson studies him.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Listen to me, professor. Forget about the letter. You got bigger fish to fry. What are you going to do about Lester Farley?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Get a restraining order, an injunction, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: A restraining order. Have you any idea what you're getting into here, Coleman? What it looks like from the outside? (leaning back in his chair) After thirty-some years of academic distinction ina community you virtually created from scratch, suddenly you've gone off the deep end. You want me, to fight a legal war for you on two fronts - one of them with a phantom correspondent and the other with a psychotic who's been locked up twice in the mental ward at the VA hospital in Northampton, under real restraints, not legal ones. Before Coleman can get in a word -

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sure I can get a restraining order, but will that restrain him? I can get you a handwriting expert. I can get you a bulletproof vest. But what I can't provide is what you're never going to know as long as you're involved with this woman: a scandal-free, Farley-free life. Is she HIV negative, by the way? Did you have her tested, Coleman? Did you use a condom, Coleman? And if you don't use protection, does SHE? How do you know she doesn't want to use you to help make up for what she's lost? Do I represent you in the paternity suit, Coleman?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I can handle Lester if I have to-

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: But why do you have to? Give up the girl, Achilles. 43. 44

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (stiffening) I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (grins) I took your intro to European lit umpteen years ago as an undergrad. Never forgot your lectures on Homer. Achilles, listen to me: you have to give up the girl. Give her up and your troubles go away. I'm speaking as your friend as well as your attorney. Faunia Farley is not in your league and she's not from your world. Last night you got a good look at her world - Coleman, the fact is she ain't worth it. (a amiable smile) Achilles on Viagra - how much sense does that make anyway? Coleman looks up at him - he's pale with fury. But when h speaks, it is with deadly quiet -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Are you quite finished? The tone gives Nelson pause. Coleman rises to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're a genuine vocal master, Nelson. And so rich with contempt for every last human problem you've never had to face.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: Listen, I was only -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You listen: I never again want to hear that self-admiring voice of yours - or see your smug, lily white face. And with that he turns and stalks out. We HOLD ON THE OPE DOOR to the outer office as Nelson's secretary sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong, Mr. Primus?  44 45 45.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON NELSON--he stands looking after Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: NELSON
dialogues.text: (to himself, perplexed) What the hell do you suppose he meant by, "lily white." WHAM! The SOUND of a PUNCH: landing -!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON AN IRISH KID--big, although he cannot be more th eighteen as he takes the jab, blinks in surprise; then la out in a fury. TIGHT ON THE YOUNG COLEMAN SILK--aged 17 as he easily ste away from his opponenent's punch, feints with his left an slams a right hook into the Irish kids mid-section. Note: As Coleman boxes, we notice the barest trace of a s on his face; he knows just how good he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEN IN A SERIES OF VERY QUICK CUTS we watch as Coleman b in on his opponent, easily dancing out of the way each ti the other boy tries to throw a punch. Over this we SUPERIMPOSE: "EAST ORANGE, NEW JERSEY 1944." Then, as the bell rings we CUT TO: WIDER ANGLE--We see we're in a GYMNASIUM, where a group o twenty-five or thirty men have crowded around a boxing ri cheering on the two young men. IN COLEMAN'S CORNER, DOC CHIZNER, Coleman's coach. A Dent in his 50's, Doc coaches kids but also referees big match in Madison Square Garden. Coleman, covered with sweat, breathing hard returns to his corner, drops onto a stool.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Coleman, wait for it! Wait for it! Let him do the work...Ah..! As Doc and the CUTMAN work him over:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Listen to me, kid. You're smarter than him, you read me? Smarter. He's a putz. You counter punch. (tapping him on the side of the face) Coleman, pay attention...  45 46 46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Coleman, breathing deeply, staring at his opponent across ring, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (continuing) Counter punch. That's your game. Just then the bell sounds. Coleman charges out. As Doc watches, Coleman puts his strategy to devastating effect -it's like previews of Mohammed Ali. Coleman danci away, dodging the punches - he's enjoying himself, enjoyi using his brains in this brawny situation... bobbing and weaving. And then - WHAM! the counter punch from nowhere. the Irish kid drops to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DOOR--as it opens and the young Coleman, carrying gym bag in one hand and a stack of books in the other, st out. He holds the door open for Doc Chizner.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Next week, West Point...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (worried) Doc, that guy's got five pounds on me. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH THE TWO MEN as they walk towards D Chizner's car.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (confident) But he's slow. You can take him easy. Besides the Pitt coach is gonna' be there. He's a buddy of mine. I want him to see you fight.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: So? They walk in silence for several beats, then:

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: So, once he sees you fight and once I tell him about your grades, I'm pretty sure he'll offer you a scholarship to Pitt.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I can't go to Pitt. My father wants me to go to Howard.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: He's an optician, your dad?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Used to be, he lost his business in the depression. By now they have reached Doc Chizner's car. . boc Look, Coleman, just box for the guy. That's all. Then let's see what happens. He starts to get into the car, stops, turns back to Colem

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: (continuing; embarrassed to be saying this) One thing. When you meet the guy from Pitt, don't tell him you're colored, okay?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Don't tell him?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: Don't bring it up. You're neither one thing or the other. You're Silky Silk. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: He won't know?

dialogues.speaker: DOC
dialogues.text: How's he gonna know? Here's the top kid from East Orange High and he's with Doc Chizner; he's gonna think you're Jewish. And with that, Doc gets into the car and drives away as w HOLD ON YOUR COLEMAN watching the car disappear a thought look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH COLEMAN--as he races down the alleyway, pus his way through a back gate and dashes up a short stairca two steps at a time. ON THE BACK DOOR--where his sister ERNESTINE, a light ski African American girl of fifteen is waiting for him.  47 48 49 48.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (an urgent whisper) You're late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Coleman pushes through the door, hands Ernestine his g bag.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I know. Hide this for me willya- THE CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they walk through the kitch toward the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Walter's home on leave -!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DOOR--as Coleman steps through the door into the dining room; it is attractively but inexpensively furnish Framed reproductions of flower painting and landscapes ar the walls. THE CAMERA PANS ACROSS TO THE DINING TABLE where the Silk family sits at dinner. Coleman's parents are light-skinne African Americans. Coleman's MOTHER is a primly attractive woman who sits ve straight in her chair - a nurse by profession. Coleman's FATHER is a barrel-chested man with intelligent features. He wears a tasteful, but inexpensive suit. The atmosphere in the room has a definite chill. ON COLEMAN--as he takes a seat next to his brother WALTER who is wearing a spiffy army uniform -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm late-- ON COLEMAN'S FATHER--who says nothing, doesn't look up at son.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (coming to Coleman's rescue) What's this I hear about you being class Valedictorian? Mr. Silk continues to eat, saying nothing. Walter throws glance toward Coleman. Coleman shrugs.  49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Just then Ernestine enters the room having stashed Colema gym bag somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Hey, with the only four point o grade average, who else were they--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Yes, we're very proud of Coleman. Nothing. Mr. Silk doesn't bother to look up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: (icy) May I inquire how you did, Coleman? TIGHT ON COLEMAN--again he shoots Walter a look, this tim Walter shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: How I did?

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Night before last, at the Knights of Pythias arena. I'm asking whether you won or lost your bout.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (furious, to Ernestine) Did you tell them? However before she can reply:

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Kindly answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (glum) I won.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: (like a prosecuting attorney) And how many fights have you won so far?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (quiet) Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: And how many have you lost?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: None, so far.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: (acid) And when are you planning on turning professional?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (coming to Coleman's defense) Dad, he's only--

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: (not bothering to even look at Walter) This does not concern you, Walter. (to Coleman) I asked you a question, young man.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (eyes averted) Doc says I could get an athletic scholarship, maybe to Pitt.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Like Walter, you will go to Howard. And after Howard, should you choose to become a doctor, you will not be doing your hands any good, pummeling them in a boxing ring. (getting to his feet) You know, if I were your father, Coleman, you know what I'd tell you now?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You are my father.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: I'm not at all sure. I was thinking that Doc Chizner was your father.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: He's my coach, that's all. He teaches me how to fight. You're my father.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Well if I were your father, you know what I'd tell you now?  Sl.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (his voice a whisper) What.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: I would say, "You won last night. Good. Now you can retire undefeated." (firm) You're retired. (getting to his feet) Now, if you'll excuse me, I don't want to miss my train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled with DINERS and uniformed WAITERS bustling among w tablecloths, Mr. Silk, among them, carrying an overloaded TRAY.

dialogues.speaker: DINER
dialogues.text: Boy, this fish is overcooked...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir...

dialogues.speaker: DINER
dialogues.text: I'd like to change my order...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SILK
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, very good, sir,... He picks up the man's plate, puts it on the laden tray al with food, glasses and utensils, starts back to the galle Suddenly he collapses, bringing down dishes with a CRASH! that startles everyone in the dining car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dreary spot. A knot of MOURNERS across from Mr. Silk's coffin. Mrs. Silk upright as always, her hair now tinged with GREY, a handkerchief to her mouth, holds Ernestine's hand. Ernestine's tears stream silently down...  51 52 52.

dialogues.speaker: THE MINISTER
dialogues.text: "Cowards die many times before their deaths; the valiant never taste of death but once." Clarence Silk knew well those lines from Julius Caesar. But I don't think there's any question here about who was valiant. PAN TO COLEMAN, stunned - The coffin now lowered into the ground...

dialogues.speaker: THE MINISTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ashes to ashes...

dialogues.speaker: INT., (COLEMAN'S)
dialogues.text: At first we don't know where we are. Then a DOOR is opene revealing a SILHOUETTE -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Coleman?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Leave it off...Please...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Alright. She closes the door and walks tentatively towards Coleman who lies in his bed. Gradually, our eyes become accustome the dark; his mother sits on the edge of the bed. She's in her crisp, starched white NURSE'S UNIFORM -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You on duty? Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: It's better this way. For me, anyway...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I never knew him. Not really. I didn't have any idea what he went through. Every... (on the verge of saying "godamned" but checks himself in front of his mother) ...Single day...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: I don't believe he wanted you to know, dear. He couldn't see the point.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I can see the point. The point is if you're Colored it doesn't matter how much you know, you work in the dining car. That's the point.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Coleman, if it's your education, you don't have to worry. Your father's insurance and your own academic record will see to it that you get into Howard.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Mom, Howard isn't ‘a real university. Howard's no different from East Orange.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: (sharp) Coleman!

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (he must make himself heard, despite the cost) I heard all about Howard from Walt. He said they're always talking about "the negro people." About "We the negro people." Mom, I'm not a "political" person. I don't know who this "we" is.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Your father wanted you to know who you were; to be proud of your race.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (with passion) What about me?! What about just being proud of being me? I don't want to be part of some group. I don't want to be "a Howard Negro."

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Coleman, your father wanted the best for you. He--  54.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: And what about what I want?! It's my life! Don't I get any say in the matter? (softening his tone) Mom, I just want a chance to be the best I can be. Why is that so wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: I'm ‘not clever enough to argue with you, Coleman...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (he puts an arm around her) Then don't. Don't let's argue. I love you, Mom, but don't ask me to go there...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Coleman... you're barely eighteen; what're you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scores of YOUNG MEN filling out forms. PAN THE ROOM TO RE A large CALENDAR with the date - October 6, 1944 and seve propaganda POSTERS which inform us that "There's still a to be won" in the Pacific, "One down, One to Go" etc. DISCOVER COLEMAN staring at his application form. HIS POV: on the query demanding his age and date of birth Coleman fills out the data, then looks over to -

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT QUESTION
dialogues.text: The form offers WHITE, NEGRO, ORIENTAL, OTHER Coleman stares at the boxes - WHITE... NEGRO... Instinctively he looks around the room before returning h scrutiny to the categories. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WHITE.
dialogues.text: WIDER ANGLE--as Coleman hands the form to the NAVY RECRUI a young man (white) in a crisp white uniform. He studies form, looks up at Coleman. CLOSE ON COLEMAN--certain that he has been found out.

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL RECRUITER
dialogues.text: {a big smile) Welcome to the Navy, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN, who looks up from the letter, which he has just r

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: So what did the lawyer say? Coleman, still dressed as at Primus', paces, irritated, confused -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: He wouldn't even discuss the letter, he just... Well, he ~

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (not really a guestion) Was more worried about Lester Farley? COLEMAN . I don't want to talk about Lester Farley..!

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (hands him the glass) What DO you want to talk about? You show up here, all in a lather - Silence, as Coleman struggles with his emotions. Nathan studies him, then, softly -

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Listen, I was at the post office this morning, I heard people saying you got Faunia Farley pregnant, that she had an abortion and tried to kill herself--

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Did they add she's an opium eater, while they were at it? And don't forget the best part, she's an "illiterate woman"!  56.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Coleman, I know it's bullshit, I'm your friend, remember ~-? Coleman bangs down the glass of ice tea -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Then act like it.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Coleman, don't take these people on. (gesturing toward the television where the impeachment hearings are playing) They're all crazy to blame, crazy to punish-

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: So I just throw her to the wolves? (Realizes) She's waiting for that. To her, sex and betrayal are as basic as bread.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I'm not thinking about her. I'm thinking about you. But Coleman is cranking up...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Christ, my own kids - I never allowed any of them to watch TV and they manifest the mentality of a soap opera. The best schools, superior SAT scores, post graduate degrees and where their father's concerned, Jerry Springer is the best they can do -?? Don't be like them.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (helpless) I don't know what you want me to Say...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I want you to acknowledge that something important is taking place between me and this woman - something worthy of respect. Don't judge me.  57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 55 COLEMAN (cont'd) And for heavens sake don't judge her. Nathan is flummoxed, having trouble following...

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: She's - what are you telling me? She's the love of your life?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, look, granted, she's not my first love and granted, she's not my Great Love, okay? But she's sure as hell my Last Love. Isn't that worth something? Isn't it? And he opens the door and walks out into the night

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: And with my failure to reach him, all the doors but one had been slammed in Coleman's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman and Faunia together after making love, listening "The Man I Love"... she's smoking...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Dance for me. (her look) Dance. Undismayed and naked, Faunia stubs out the cigarette, get out of bed and undulates to sultry Gershwin.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: This is more than sex.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: No, it's not... You just forgot what sex is. Don't fuck it up by pretending it's something else. STAY with Coleman, watching, not a depleted old man, but lover... Faunia's performance darkly reflected in an anti oval MIRROR above the head of the bed just over Coleman.. She dances. He watches. A connection between them... Faunia is not se conscious.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her movements are small, not dancing really, rather rhythmically exhibiting herself in tiny gestures for him. Then in a series of slow dissolves as THE CAMERA MOVES IN

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't fall in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Keep dancing...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (dancing) You're falling in love... Look at you, Coleman, you're a little boy in love with his piano teacher. You're much too young for me. (she smiles) I need a much older man. At least a hundred. You know anyone in a wheelchair?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: I can't stop...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: This is all there is.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: Now you're talking. Stay angry. Angry brings us together. Lemme tell you, pal, you picked the right dancing girl...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You're wiser than your years...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: I'm dumber than my years. Being stupid, that's my achievement. Turns out I've been watching you dance. I know all about you, Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: That a fact? She's dancing closer to him now, her body glistening -  55 56 57 59.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: You imagine you've kept secrets from me?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You never know...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: What could there possibly be I don't know about you by now..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a beautiful young girl (STEENA); she is blond an cannot be more than nineteen. Hers is the FACE we saw in PHOTO with Coleman earlier. Just now she's alone-

dialogues.speaker: ED HERLIHY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The war is over and hundreds of thousands of American soldiers, REVERSE ON THE NEWSREEL she's watching -

dialogues.speaker: ED HERLIHY
dialogues.text: sailors and airmen are returning to a grateful nation where, thanks to Uncle Sam, a college education awaits, courtesy of the GI Bill..! As the newsreel about the GI bill continues, We CUT TO: COLEMAN SILK, now 21 wearing a tweed jacket and looking v collegiate. He sits several rows behind Steena; his eyes fixed on her. Then, just as he is about to make a move to her, three young women crowd in on either side of Steena they all begin whispering and giggling among themselves. Reluctantly, Coleman gets to his feet and starts up the a of the theater, throwing one last look over his shoulder, towards the girl as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON COLEMAN--He moves through the stacks, carrying a coupl books; clearly searching for another. He pauses, about to remove a book from the shelf when he looks O.S.: HIS POV: In the distance we get a glimpse of the beautifu blond girl we saw in the movie theater. She instantly disappears; and for a moment Coleman isn't sure whether w he saw was real or an apparition. CLOSER ON COLEMAN (TRACKING WITH HIM)--he instantly start hot pursuit of the girl.  60.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 58 As he reaches the end of the row; he stops, looks around. HIS POV--At first there is no sign of the blond. Then he spots her disappearing into another row of books. ON COLEMAN (AGAIN TRACKING WITH HIM) as he ducks into ano row of books, moving parallel with her, intending to head off. COLEMAN'S POV (TRACKING SHOT): looking though the shelves get a glimpse: of the blond several rows away. Once again disappears. ON COLEMAN--brushing past a browser in the stacks.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Throughout this we are continually CROSS-CUTTING BETWEEN COLEMAN, AND HIS POV OF THE GIRL (never getting more than glimpses of her). ON COLEMAN as he rounds a corner and stops dead in his tr HIS POV: There is the blond, she stands not far away, her back to him, still intent on the book she is reading. TIGHT ON COLEMAN--There is a half smile on his lips; the half smile we saw in the boxing ring. TIGHTER ON THE BLOND--Her back is still to us.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Hi... As she turns TO CAMERA we see her for the first time and realize that she really is that beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DOOR--as it is unlocked and Coleman brings the blo in...

dialogues.speaker: BLOND
dialogues.text: I really shouldn't -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: One cup of coffee, that's all. I promise. Library stays open til five... As he leads her inside we see his apartment for the first time. It is an attractive one room apartment with a simpl fireplace and a kitchenette off to one side.  61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The walls are white, there are reproductions of Paul Klee Chagall. The bookshelves are one by eights with bricks at each end serving as risers. There are books everywhere, o every surface; on the table we see a pair of boxing glove (not the kind you use in the ring, but lighter ones, the fighters use for work on the heavy bag). The bed has been carefully made, dishes put away; the impression we get is of order and neatness.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: GI bill pays for all this..? ON COLEMAN--as he begins fixing coffee.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: How do you take it. I'm sorry, say your name again..? Steena -?

dialogues.speaker: BLOND
dialogues.text: Steena Palsson... black is fine... How'd you get that cut over your eye?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Steena... What is that, Swedish?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Close. Norwegian. I really should-

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You're not from New York...

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed smile) How could you tell? Fergus Falls, Minnesota. He walks over to her, smiling -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You're making that up, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: No, I - He's standing so close, she's desperate for a diversion- something...

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (continuing) You weren't kidding... that cut... She picks up his BOXING GLOVES -  62.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: It's just a hobby. Ever tried?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Me? Are you -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Here... very therapeutic...

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: I dunno...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (holding up his hands, palms out) C'mon, try it. Live a little.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Coleman -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. Now - (he helps her adjust her arms) Right handed? Okay, you use your right to punch, but you keep your left up, like so... (he gently positions her left hand beside her face) ..this protects you. Now you jab with your right. Try a few jabs. She does; aiming at his open palms.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's it...Now, use your feet, dance with me. She continues to throw jabs, relaxing, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you smart - ?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (breathless) Smart - ? He easily takes hold of both her hands in his; now he is close to her.  63.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Boxing is really all about how smart you are... He leans forward, kissing her lightly. Then again. Then again, this time she moves toward the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (sudden thought) Do you do this a lot..?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (smiles reassuringly) Practice makes perfect. He's kissing her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GLOVES on the floor, RISE UP TO REVEAL the two of the lying in bed together. She's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: I can't believe this. Coleman grins -

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean I can't believe I did something like this...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Waiting for lightning to strike you dead..?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Well... Where I come from -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Fergus Falls, Minnesota...

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: People don't just hop into -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Let me guess. First there's eyeing one another in church on Sundays...
59 COLEMAN (cont'd) then, as fall slips into winter and the air turns cold, there's sleigh rides, skating on frozen lakes, singing Carols around the Yuletide-

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Very funny...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Go on then, give me the straight dope. Tell me about real American courtship...

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (startled) You're American. Jews are American. He's kissing her again - and again she's succumbing -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON COLEMAN AND STEENA--as they round the corner of a stre near NYU. THE CAMERA MOVES WITH STEENA AND COLEMAN as they walk, their arms around one another.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: So all I'm saying is that Achilles is the first real individual in all of western litera--

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Not a chance... (grins) Look, Achilles succumbed to to group pressure, right? I mean, he gave up the girl - a girl he really wanted - so the Greeks could keep going with the Trojan war. He gave in to group pressure.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: From which you conclude what - that groups are -?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Is this the same conversation?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I'd say you were maybe five, ten, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Where is this le-

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Did you play basketball in high school?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: And I bet you were good.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Well, I -

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: But let me ask you this. Did you want to play?

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Did I -?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: In America, if you're a girl and you're five ten they make you play basketball. It's a given. They don't ask if you want to play, if you're interested in the game. Height equals fate. You play. You do what the group says.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: I like basketball...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: What if it were something you didn't like? Say all girls over five ten had to shave their heads. They are both laughing, Steena turns and looks at Coleman with a look of total adoration

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Coleman... I think I'm in love with you. At that moment we HEAR a click. The picture freezes and t to black and white. It is the snapshot Nathan Zuckerman s in Coleman's house earlier.  60 61 66.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON A STREET PHOTOGRAPHER--He has just taken the photograp saw earlier in the scene with Nathan. The one Coleman has kept all these years and now we know why.

dialogues.speaker: STREET PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: (handing Coleman a card) Picture of you and your sweetheart for a dollar? As Coleman happily digs in his pocket we HEAR: Dick Hayme singing "Our Love Is Here To Stay."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is in the days when LPs and 45s first came out; there bins filled with hit singles. Dick Haymes continues to si as we see Steena and Coleman in a listening booth. Colema comes out to look for another record as Steena remains in booth continuing to listen to a record. THE CAMERA PANS A OF HIM TO REVEAL a very pretty young salesgirl, she is a coffee colored African American. Her name is ELLIE and sh watches Coleman with interest. We move with her as she crosses to a bin where Coleman is flipping through 78s.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (glancing up) I was...looking for Edith Piaf, "La Vie un Rose."

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: This way.. THE CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM--she walks very close to him s that they brush against one another.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing; innocent) Have you heard the new Louis Armstrong?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: No, I'm not--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (amused) What about "Black and Tan Suite?" It's the best thing Ellington's done in--  67.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm really not--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (nodding O.S.) That your girlfriend? HER POV: Steena in the booth, moving gently in time to th music.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (flirting) Here... (she hands him a 78 record) Take this, Roy Eldridge, "The Man I Love." This'1ll do the job a hell of a lot better than Edith Piaf. We HEAR ~- THE MAN I LOVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON COLEMAN AND STEENA--in a passionate embrace, as come up for air. Although "The Man I Love" continues to p we are close enough to Coleman and Steena to be aware of their breathing.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Dance for me... CLOSER ON STEENA--She steps away, looking Coleman in the for a long, long beat as she comes to a decision. Then, w the arest trace of a smile, she removes first one earring then the other. She begins a languid, undulating motion as she takes Coleman's hand, opens it and drops the two earrings into palm. Then, continuing the slow rhythmic movements begins undress slowly. This should be a very different Steena from the girl who first walked into Coleman's apartment; some deep, erotic of her has been unlocked and at moments she displays a wa moving that is uncannily like Faunia's. In a series of SL DISSOLVES we watch as she strips to the sensual music of Gershwin.  62 63 68.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: By the end, when she has removed her last undergarment an dances in front of Coleman absolutely naked, the record c to an end and we hear the scratching of the needle of the record player on vinyl. It is as though at that moment sh comes out of a trance. She immediately puts her hands to face to cover her embarrasment.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) That has got to be the single most sexy dance ever to be danced by a girl from Fergus Falls in the history of the world. ON STEENA--her hands remain covering her face; both morta embarrassed and profoundly exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Coleman, I love you. I want to spend my life with you.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing Sunday? CLOSER ON STEENA--She lowers her hands from her face.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: (in answer to the question we heard the older Coleman ask) Sunday? Nothing. Why?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: On Sunday we're taking the train to New Jersey... {a beat) To have dinner with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman and Steena walk towards his house. Steena is carr FLOWERS. Coleman points out various landmarks.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: ...that's where I crashed my bike into old man Harris' front porch... My dad made me pay-- Just then we HEAR:  63 64 65 69.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (calling out) Coleman. Coleman looks 0.S. waves. THEIR POV: Across the street a young man (African America a few years older than Coleman waves. ON COLEMAN AND STEENA--Coleman waves back, then quickly glances in Steena's direction to see her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON COLEMAN AND STEENA--His arm is around her, he leans forward, presses the bell and turns to Steena.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (very nervous) I love you, you know that don't you? Before she can answer the door opens and there is Mrs. Si her hair is grayer, but otherwise she looks the same.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Well, isn't this lovely. (she kisses her son, then to Steena) Hello, you must be Steena...Please Come in... TIGHT ON STEENA--She has been brought up very well and, although her world has just collapsed around her, her man are impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: I brought you these...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Aren't they beautiful? I'll just put them in water... She leads them in as the DOOR closes on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman, his mother and Steena at dinner - the dining roo looks a little empty with only three... As she speaks, St seems to be breathing in all the wrong places... Mrs. Silk is wise enough to understand what her son has n told Steena; therefore she does everything in her power t make this poor girl more comfortable.  65 66 70.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: .»..it's a beautiful city, Fergus Falls, unusual because it has the Otter Tail Lake just to the East... My father has a hardware supply store and a small lumberyard ~ he's the disorganized one, cuts himself and doesn't even bother to wash it; they're tough, those Icelanders - I didn't even know they were called Icelanders. My mother, she's a Rasmussen - she's the opposite: sets the table for Saturday dinner at five the night before. I guess I was caught between the two extremes, so I decided to get away for college, you know, out of their reach, and...that's how I came to New York... A caesura in her breathless delivery... Steena looking pathetically around, then -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: I've never been to the mid-west but I'm sure I'd like it. Coleman, wouldn't you like to see the mid west? Steena, would you like another biscuit? Steena's look of gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman and Steena, virtually alone in the chair car, hea back for the city. Steena leans against the window, silen staring out into the night. Coleman sits next to her, watching her carefully, holding her hand.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Steena? Silence, then with the screeching of brakes the train pul to a stop. The conductor (black) walks through the car, announcing Penn Station, the final stop. The people get u and leave the car, still Steena doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Honey...?  71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 67 CLOSE ON STEENA--as she turns to Coleman, we see for the first time that she has been crying. She looks at him for long beat, just shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: STEENA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Coleman, I...I love you but-- (she breaks off) I can't. I'm really sorry, but... (shaking her head) I just...can't...I'm sorry...I'm sorry... And without another word, blind with tears, she flees. Coleman doesn't go after her. He just sits there. Alone. As we FADE TO BLACK we hear the roar of a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT--of the crows, still relatively sparse since it the first or decond match of the evening. THE CAMERA PANS ACROSS TO THE RING where an AFRICAN AMERICAN BOXER waits, bouncing up and down, throwing punches at the air, REVERSE ON THE YOUNG COLEMAN as he climbs through the rop along with his CORNERMAN who is African- American. SOLLY, small time fight promoter who manages Coleman, climbs up leans in and whispers to Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: SOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey, Silky...Take it easy with the nigger, okay? Let's give the people their money's worth. Coleman stares 0.S. at the fighter, his face a mask.

dialogues.speaker: SOLLY
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiling) Dance him around for three, four rounds, then go to work. The bell sounds, Coleman moves into the ring more rapidly than usual. The formalities over, the men begin to feel o another out. We notice that the usual smile is gone from Coleman's face; it has been replaced by a look of grim determination. After one or two punches, Coleman nails his opponent with right cross and then methodically begins to pound the bla fighter, knocking him out before the round is half way ov There are boos from the crowd.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman's African American cornerman stripping off his gloves, gear, as Solly returns, studies Coleman, who does look up-

dialogues.speaker: SOLLY
dialogues.text: I ask you nicely to give folks their money's worth. You could have stopped the nigger in the fourth round instead of the first.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (doesn't look up) I'm a hundred thirty-nine pounds, five foot nine and this guy's one forty-five, five foot eleven. I'm supposed to let him hit me in the head five, ten extra times to put on a show? (looks up) I ain't holding up no nigger. The cornerman doesn't react ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a nightclub in the Village, late at night. Coleman dancing with ELLIE (the pretty girl from the record store The music is slow and they are dancing very close togethe

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: What are you anyway, Coleman Silk?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: What am I? Play it anyway you like.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: So white girls thinks you're white?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Whatever they think, I let them think.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: And what about your family, do they know about this?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I don't see what good it would do to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: And me? What about me?  73.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: A guy from school saw us the other day and said, "What's it like with a colored girl." And I told him, "Man, they are completely hot." Ellie laughs, moves even closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Then let's let them know how right you were. She leans up and kisses him; he kisses her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. HOLD FOR A BEAT then:

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Coleman?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: You think what I'm doing is wrong? ON COLEMAN--He stands at a window, looking out into the n ON ELLIE--as she reaches across, turns on a bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (reaching for a cigarette) Passing? CLOSER ON COLEMAN~-as he turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: But that's just it. I don't tell people I'm white; I don't tell them I'm Jewish. Oh, I know it's passing in one sense, but it's not because I want to be white. It isn't. I don't want to be white.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (weary) Well, honey, you sure don't want to be colored. (then: ) What happened with your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: We broke up.  70 71 74.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Did she know you were passing? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Did you ever tell her you were paying for your Ph.D in a boxing ring? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) How come? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (continuing; with a sigh) I'm starting to think you're right. This isn't about you being colored or white. Coleman Silk, I'm starting to think this is about you being the kind of man who just loves having secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rally to save the Rosenbergs from execution. IRIS GITTE (20's), waving a PLACARD and awkwardly offering a PETITIO Attractive, she's dressed in earth tones and Navajo jewel We recognize her at once because of her flamboyant hair..

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Save the Rosenbergs! Sign now! There's no time to lose! Save the Rosenbergs! Hey, buddy -! Justice- She literally yanks the guy around to face her. It's Cole He wears a smart tie with his tweed jacket and, as always packs BOOKS - which now go flying... Iris is doubly startled - and flustered. Coleman is movie star handsome. He crackles with sexual electricity.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey, sorry... Embarrassed by his great looks, she clumsily ditches her placard, clunking him on the head with it - Oy!  71 72 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she squats to help him retrieve the volumes, she's blushing-

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) So, you gonna sign the petition..?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (picking up books) I'm not really a political person -

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: What's that mean? You'll potchke in front of a blackboard while the Rosenbergs get the chair?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (amused) I suppose you think Alger Hiss is innocent, as well...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Alger Hiss is as innocent as you are! FREEZE FRAME on Coleman's reaction: she thinks I'm innoce CLOSE ON A PHOTOGRAPH OF IRIS, featuring her fly away hai PULL BACK TO REVEAL;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Coleman's mother studies the photo. Coleman sits oppos her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Iris. Nice name. And when is the happy day?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: June 14.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: June 14. She's white, of course. (pause) Have you told her?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: When will you? (no reply) You plan on bringing her here for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You saw what happened when I tried that. Their eyes lock. Mrs. Silks suddenly understands - pow.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing; quietly) I told her my parents are dead.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Dead... that you have no brother, you have no sister. There is no Ernestine. There is no Walter.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I don't want to be Coleman Silk, the Negro classics professor - and that's how it would always come out, Mom. You know it and I know it. He speaks urgently, desperate for her to understand -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Funny, I never thought of you as black or white. Gold. You were my golden child...

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Mom, look, I haven't worked the whole thing out, I'm just -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: Will you have children?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I suppose... Mrs. Silk won't raise her voice -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: You're never going to let them see me, are you? My grandchildren? Mom, you'll tell me, sit in the waiting room in Penn Station at 11:25am. I'll walk by with my kids in their Sunday best.  77.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MRS. SILK (cont'd) That'll be my birthday present five years from now. And you know I'll be there. The train station, the zoo, Central Park - wherever you say. Or maybe you can hire me to come over as Mrs. Brown to baby sit. I'll do it. Put them to bed and clean your house. But aren't you taking a risk having children? The suspense will be unbearable. Suppose they don't emerge from her womb as white as you? Won't you have some explaining to do? Will you accuse her of adultery? With a Negro? But she'll know that isn't true... She picks up Iris' photo and realizes -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Maybe it won't come to that. Look at that hair. Coleman, you seem to have thought of everything. If they have hair like their mother's, that will explain away a lot, won't it? Are you marrying her for her hair?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (stiff) Of course not. (getting to his feet) I have to go now, Mom...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: You think like a prisoner, Coleman. You're white as snow and you think like a slave. He bends down kiss her; she pulls her head away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SILK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Murderer... ON COLEMAN--He straightens up, turns and as THE CAMERA TR WITH HIM, walks from the parlor, through the living room into the front hallway. Just as he is about to open the f door, he pauses, sensing something behind him as he turns

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HIS POV: Standing in the shadows in the dining room we se Mr. Silk (Coleman's father). He wears the white jacket of waiter in a railroad car; his hands are clasped in front him. He stares straight at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON COLEMAN--He reads, or pretends he is reading. We HOLD ON HIM as we HEAR: the angry noise of the buzzer fro the vestibule. Coleman's head turns at the sound, but he doesn't move. A moment later Iris appears behind him, she wearing a loose fitting robe and is in the process of dry her hair.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Who could it be, this late? Instantly Coleman is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Coleman steps outside. HIS POV: Through the mesh grill we see a shadowy figure i the vestibule. ON THE DOOR as Coleman opens it to reveal Walter, older, heavier and now wearing civilian clothes. Walter grabs Coleman shoves him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Don't you ever come near Mom again.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Walt, wait a--

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You don't call, you don't write, you don't nothing! He lets go of his brother, looks at him with utter contem

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (continuing) I never want to see your lily- white face again. And he turns and walks away. Over this we HEAR:  79.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: With Coleman's decision his fate was decided...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is black. THE CAMERA PANS DOWN and we see the of a brightly lit Chinese restaurant. THE CAMERA CONTINUE IT'S MOVE and we see a scattering of cars in the parking As we watch a black van pulls to a stop in front of the restaurant...

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Everything was prepared for what was now inevitable. One of the van doors opens and a man in his fifties (BOBC gets out.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Though many years in the future. CLOSER IN ON LESTER FARLEY--He sits is the passenger seat staring straight ahead; he has a cigarette in his mouth a is trying to light it, but his hand is shaking so that he can't

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Les...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Can't do it, Louie...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Yes you can. It'ss just a Chinese restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You don't get it they're gooks in there

dialogues.speaker: BOBCAT
dialogues.text: They're Chinese Les, not Vietnamese.  80.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (turning on him ina fury) Asshole! I don't care what the fuck they are! They count as gooks!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (calming Les down) I know how hard it is, buddy, but you know you can trust me and I'm telling you: you can do this. Still Lester Farley doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tell you what - you wanna leave after soup and we're out of here, "kay? We're gone. Say the word.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: What word - ?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: We'll have a code word. Say the code word and we split, we're gone. Les, listen to me: how you gonna see the Wall when it comes to Pittsfield if you don't-

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Told you! Ain't going to see the fuckin' wall...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That's what they all say at first. Les, I know, I been there. Look at me, Les - I'm twelve years off drugs. I'mclean. I stick to my meds. I know what the Wall does for vets like us. Trust me, it'll work for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A LARGE TABLE--The Vets are all seated - Chet and Bobc flank Les, in case anything goes wrong. Swift is doing al the talking.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFT
dialogues.text: You know what pisses me off about these pussies from the Gulf War? Their biggest problem is they can't go to the fuckin' beach.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SWIFT (cont'd) They--

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (startled by something 0.S.) What's he doin'?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: He's the owner, Les. His name is Henry. He only wants to help...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I gotta’ get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Not yet. Let's focus on soup - what kind of soup are you having, Les?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Uh. Uh... What are you guys having?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFT
dialogues.text: Wonton -

dialogues.speaker: BOBCAT
dialogues.text: Wonton -

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What about it Les? Lester manages a nod.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) ‘kay we're all having Wonton. Now we're gonna order the other stuff. Les, you want chicken, vegetables, pork? You want lo mein? Noodles -? From the corner of his eye, Les sees a CHINESE WAITER beg his approach - his eyes widen with hatred and fear...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: What the fuck -

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Can you stay back please? Five wonton soups! Just give us a minute; we'll come to you - Baffled, the man steps back uncertainly; Louis turns to L

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Double sauteed pork? Double sauteed pork for Les. Okay, concentrate, Les - Chet, will you pour some tea? The Waiter moves forward to help again ~- Chet pours tea.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Just keep the fucking waiter -

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Sir, sir! Sir, if you just stay there, we'll come to you with our order - just... keep a distance. Okay? Right. You stay there. Perfect. Okay, Les?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFT
dialogues.text: You're doing real good. I remember my first time. Thought I'd never make it. Couldn't even open the fucking menu...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: What's the fucking code word?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Tea leaf. Just say tea leaf and we're out of here... The waiter emerges from the kitchen with the soup. Instan Chet and Swift head off the waiter and take the tray...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (to Louie, his voice low) This almost over? Because I'm tellin' you now I can't take much more. I can't fucking take any more...

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I don't hear the code word, Les, so we're gonna keep going - SIR, will you please stay back! Just, stay back - ! We'll bring our order... The Waiter stops. CLOSE ON LES--trying to spoon his soup - his hand is shak  83.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're doing great, Les...You're doin' just great. Over this we HEAR a pianist playing Prokofiev.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A PIANIST--wearing a sweater and jeans is playing Prokofiev. Behind him we see a small chamber group also casually dressed. The pianist stops almost mid-phrase as violinst comes over to him and the two men begin to discu the music in whispers. Over this we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: I had been both missing Coleman and missing the experience of having an intimate friend,.. ON THE AUDIENCE--a handful of people, dressed as casually the performers are scattered around the concert hall used chamber groups. Behind them, through a large opening we c see the Berkshires in the distance. ON NATHAN--He appears at the side moving through rows of empty seats (some of which have sweaters draped over the to mark them as occupied) looking for a chair. Meanwhile rehearsal begins again.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...SO I drove to Tanglewood to listen to a rehearsal of the evening's performance. CLOSER IN ON NATHAN-~-as he takes his seat and spots some

dialogues.speaker: O.S.
dialogues.text: HIS POV: Coleman and Faunia are seated several rows ahead Nathan. We see Coleman lean across and whisper something Faunia. She smiles, but says nothing in response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is intermission, Coleman and Faunia are huddled togeth he is talking as she lights a cigarette. She is listening although it is obvious that she is very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Coleman. Coleman looks up, a flash of panic in his eyes.  84.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (then smiling) Nathan, I thought I saw you... what a surprise... (to Faunia) You remember Nathan Zuckerman. Coleman takes a gentle hold of Faunia's arm so that she w not bolt this time.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (neutral) I remember.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (stepping quickly in) Mr. Bronfman's something isn't he? I was telling Faunia that he took ten years at least out of that piano

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I was thinking along those lines myself. (a beat, then:) I've missed you, Coleman. Maybe I can take you two to dinner some night.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (once more a flicker of panic) Good idea. Yes. Let's do that. The Intermission BELL RINGS. Coleman tries to hide relief

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Uh oh, we've got to run. He's pulling Faunia away but Nathan can't help himself.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Coleman!

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I'll call you! As he hurries her away into the crowd we HEAR:  718 719 80 85.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: I tried to use my imagination - not to speculate where they went. That wasn't hard. But rather to ponder what their mutual rage had made of them: outcasts, alone together, they were now stripped down to the simplest version of themselves. With nothing between them and their destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON FAUNIA-~-as she leans over, kisses Coleman.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Stay here tonight. She shakes her head, smiles...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you... (kissing him again) I never stay the night. Although she has said this many times, her heart isn't in

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (leaning forward to kiss her gently) Just this once. We FADE TO BLACK:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON COLEMAN--He sits at the kitchen table, reading the New York Times. A cup of coffee is in front of him and laid o on the table is an elegant breakfast: orange juice, toast a silver toast rack, eggs benedict (in a covered plate to keep them warm). He looks up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Good morning. REVERSE ON FAUNIA--She stands in the doorway, wearing sweatpants and a worn tee shirt.  86.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sit down, your eggs will get cold. Faunia sits; she has the look of an animal whose instinct sense a trap.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing; making conversation) Doesn't look like Monica is going to find a job in New York any time soon. Faunia stares at the plate in front of her - HER POV - beautifully prepared eggs benedict... Coleman r

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) "According to Vernon Jordan--

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: Can't you avoid the fucking seminar?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (looks up at her) I was only - Faunia hurls her cup of coffee across the room, shatterin and its contents against the cabinets -

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: I don't give a fuck that poor Monica can't find a job! Does fucking Monica worry if my back hurts from milking those fucking cows? Does she worry about me sweeping up people's shit at the fucking post office? You think losing your job when you're about to retire anyway is a big deal, it's not, I hate to-tell you. Having your step-father put his fingers in your cunt, that's a big deal; a husband who comes up behind you with an iron pipe and hits you in the head that's a big deal...having two kids suffocating and dying, that's a big deal!  87.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 81 82 83 84 FAUNIA (cont'd) (tears starting) Shit... (looking around like a trapped animal) Why did I fucking stay?! It was a mistake. Even fucking whores know better: "Men don't pay you to sleep with them. They pay you to go home." And she runs out of the house and leaving him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same twisting two lane we saw at the start. Faunia's Chevy squealing around curves... The Chevy passes the SIGN at the head of a dirt road: AUD SOCIETY - where Coleman first gave her a lift. Her big ca squeals to a STOP out of FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faunia leaning on the wheel, thinking. Crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gray-shingled two story house nestled in the woods. WIN CHIMES. Once a residence, now the start of trails into th bird sanctuary... Faunia's Chevy bumps uncertainly into the parking area an stops. Faunia gets out, walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A CAGE with a crow (PRINCE) inside; he moves bac and forth in an excited manner.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi Prince... THE CAMERA WIDENS IT'S ANGLE--and we see Faunia approachi the cage and the bird getting as close to her as it can.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (softly) How are you doing my Prince? ON A DOOR LEADING TO THE OFFICE--inside a young girl is feeding an animal; she sees Faunia, who is obviously a regular visitor.  88.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. (nodding toward the cage) He got out the other day.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: But he always comes back, don't you, boy? Can I have him on my shoulder? Honey, it's Faunia... The Bird watches her from within its cage.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You can try, but he won't come out of his cage if he thinks you want him to - Faunia opens the cage and holds out her hand, but Prince won't budge -

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I know all his little tricks, don't I, Prince? (over her shoulder) He was famous in Seely Falls when I lived there, used to go for all the bright objects in the parking lot, barrettes in the girls' hair, keys and tin foil. The newspaper wrote him up... all about the folks who raised him after the nest was destroyed...one.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, we used to have the article on the bulletin board, but he pecked it all to pieces...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (laughs) He tore up his clippings? Ashamed of your background? Didn't want anyone to know about your past? Oh, you good boy, you good crow...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: He was flying around outside like I said, but the other crows started attacking him - they would've killed him. He doesn't have the right voice.  89.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: It's from being hand raised... (stroking the bird's breast) Hanging around all his life with people like us. The human stain... Suddenly Prince erupts in his own strange CAW -

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: See, he imitates the school kids who come here, but it's not the crow language and they catch on. Prince is a crow that doesn't know how to be a crow. Careful, he bites.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. Listen, he's humming! Listen, children... oh, children... CLOSE ON FAUNIA--to THE CAMERA:

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: The first time I tried was a month after they died...Oh, I was ecstatic, getting myself ready, that first time...I tried so hard... I was so happy. I remember the gin and the valium and the rat poison. It tasted bitter so I folded it into the butterscotch pudding... I was so happy... Why did they break down the door? I still don't know who did that, who ruined it... The second time my heart wasn't in it. It was just impulse and I slashed. TIGHT ON THE BIRD--watching her.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You remember, don't you, boy... ON FAUNIA--leaning close to the cage, whispering to the b

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: This morning I made a mistake. (she takes a last look) Farewell, my Prince.  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT--The travelling wall (a reproduction of Vietnam Memorial in Washington) has been set up outside a shopping mall in Pittsfield. There are a number people (family members along with Veterans)seaching for the name comrades or relatives who were killed in action. In spite the fact that it is a large crowd it is more quiet than y would expect as people move about, talking quietly among themselves... From the distance we héar a speaker.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: The people whose names are inscribed on this wall are your relatives, friends and neighbors. As the speaker continues we CUT TO: CLOSE ON THE WALL (TRACKING SHOT)--Row upon row of the na of the dead.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What's Kenny's last name? Nothing. Les is mesmerized by the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Les?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (continuing) Peterson. Kenneth Peterson... What FOLLOWS is a MONTAGE as we see couples, their arms around one another looking at the wall. A child placing a small boquet of flowers by the wall. A man about fifty, kneeling beside the wall his hand resting against the wal though it held some magical power. And all the time we continually CROSS-CUT TIGHTER AND TIGHTER ON THE NAMES. TIGHTER AND TIGHTER ON LESTER FARLEY. Finally THE CAMERA COMES TO REST ON KENNETH BRIGGS.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (nodding 0O.S.) He's right over there, Les. Lester Farley doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing; quietly) Kenny's right over there; he's waiting for you.  85 86 91.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Finally Les crosses to the wall, stands in front of Kenny name for a long beat, then drops to his knees. JUMP CUT IN TIGHT ON LES as he touches the letters a spas pain crosses his face; then he leans forward and kisses t name. ON LOUIE AND BOBCAT--deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I told you the Wall would work. He's gonna' be okay. (tears in his eyes) Les is gonna' be okay, now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coleman enters and reacts - Faunia is there. She's cleaned the whole place, putting a saucepans and wiping off the coffee-stained cupboard from morning's debacle.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: Hi... Custodial Staff... Just doing my thing... He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I went to the movies. Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. For what I did. For what I said.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You were right. What happened to me is nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: They took away everything you had, everything you did - all over one stupid word... That isn't nothing.  92.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 87 FAUNIA (cont'd) Anyways, I don't think you can measure sorrow... They've drifted towards one another; she's in his arms. T stand in the middle of the kitchen, holding one another. VERY CLOSE IN: Coleman's head rests against Faunia.

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Can you keep a secret?... She pulls away, takes his head between her hands,

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA
dialogues.text: Later. As she kisses him we DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE PICK-UP TRUCK--It is parked by the side of the roa the lights are off; it sits silent and ominous in the gra light just before dawn. Over this we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: LES' VOICE
dialogues.text: (exhausted) Numb. Fuckin' numb. No emotions. As Lester Farley continues THE CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES IN ON TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: LES' VOICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Numb to the death of my own kids. Vietnam. That's why I never did cry for my kids. He was five and she was eight. She was a stranger, my little girl. That fucking Vietnam, you caused this. My feelings are all fucked up. I said to myself, "Why can't I feel?" I said, "Why didn't I save them? Why couldn't I save them?" I kept thinking about Vietnam. About all the times I think I died. By now we are close enough to see the silhouette of leste Farley, slumped down on the driver's side. He lights a cigarette and for an instant we see his face.  87 88 89 90 93.

dialogues.speaker: LES' VOICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's how I began to know I can't die. Because I died already. LESTER'S POV; (TELEPHOTO SHOT): In the distance, from aro a turn we see the lights of a car approaching. It is the identical shot from the opening of the film.

dialogues.speaker: LES' VOICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Because I died already in Vietnam. TIGHT ON LESTER--he leans forward, turns on the ignition ON THE TRUCK--as the headlights turn on. Again, it is the identical shot from the opening of the film. As the truck pulls away we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan asleep, is awakened by the telephone. Groggily, he fumbles for the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Hello..? As he listens we hear from the distance, "Bewitched, Both and Bewildered." playing on the radio:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT--It is a summer night, Coleman and Nathan are dancing. Over this we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: COLEMAN
dialogues.text: I hear that and everything within me unclenches and the wish not to die, never to die is almost too great to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A GRAY SKY--we see crows circling overhead THE CAMERA DOWN past a frozen waterfall; in the F.G. is a precipice where a handful of people have gathered. THE CAMERA COMES REST ON NATHAN ZUCKERMAN standing at the edge of the crow HIS POV: of the mourners. A small woman with granny glass (SALLY) is speaking.  94.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We all lived with Faunia up at the farm and that's why we are here this morning, to celebrate a life. Faunia Farley was, as you know, a deeply spiritual person. As Sally's eulogy continues we PAN ACROSS TO NATHAN who i looking O.S. HIS POV:Among the mourners we notice an older, aristocrat looking couple (FAUNIA'S MOTHER AND STEP-FATHER); she wea a fur coat, he is perfectly groomed. They look very out o place.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Not a word about the accident itself. And certainly not a word to suggest what I knew without a doubt - that it had been no accident. CLOSE ON A PAIR OF HANDS--holding an urn; as we watch it tipped and Faunia's ashes spill out into the river below; moment later the box containing the ashes of Faunia's children is held up and it is overturned as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a blank wall, the lighting is flourescent and institutional. In the FOREGROUND we see Lester Farley. He being interviewed by a PSYCHOLOGIST. What we are watching videotape.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: They thought the Wall had saved me, but I faked them out. Use my vehicle, that was the plan. Along the river, come right at them, same lane... suicide mission...

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: At what point did you get in your truck?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: This is all confidential, right?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Ummm. . .

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: After dark.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. 95. 91

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Had you had dinner?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No dinner.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Why did you get in the truck?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: To get him.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: To get who?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: The Jew professor.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Why were you going to get him?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Because I had to.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Why did you have to?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: (continuing) You were going to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, all of us.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: There was planning then.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No planning.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: You knew what you were doing?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: But you didn't plan it.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With that the screen suddenly goes black and we CUT TO: (2)

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Did you think you were back in Vietnam?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Were you thinking about the kids? You told me this woman killed your children. Was this payback?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No payback.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Weren't you trying to get revenge, to take revenge for that?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No revenge.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Were you depressed?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No, no depression.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
