dialogues.text: Angry?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No more anger.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: But you drove your truck into their car?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I didn't kill them.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Then who killed them?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (he smiles for the first time) They killed themselves. 96. 91  97.

dialogues.text: We see the PSYCHOLOGIST who interviewed Lester Farley wit his SUPERVISING DOCTOR; they have been watching a videota

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISOR
dialogues.text: Did you check the police report?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (writing as he is talking) Were there any marks on Farley's truck that would indicate a collision with Silk's car?

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: No, but he could--

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (he continues to write) Any signs on Coleman Silk's car that he was sideswiped by Farley's truck? The psychologist shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (continuing; he looks up, smiles) Delusional. Lester Farley is completely delusional, but harmless. Continue with the regular outpatient treatment. Thorazine where indicated. As he closes Lester Farley's folder we CUT TO:

93 As they walk past THE CAMERA we see Nathan behind them, listening. Just then

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER
dialogues.text: It's filth!

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S MOTHER, (0.S.)

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I wonder if I could have a word with--

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (pressing on) Coleman Silk was a friend of mine and-- The following is all overlapping.

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER
dialogues.text: (growing angry) I told you we have no--

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) He did not drive his car off the--

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Listen to the man, Charles--

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER
dialogues.text: This is insane!

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (to her husband) Stop pushing me,

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER
dialogues.text: This woman is seriously ill--  99.

dialogues.text: But you have her diary--

dialogues.speaker: FAUNIA'S STEPFATHER

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Although, I knew beyond a shadow of a doubt that Lester Farley had murdered Coleman and Faunia; whatever proof I had was gone. What could I do about it? What should I do about it? We HEAR: BACH'S FUGUE in D MINOR -

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN'S VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: By contrast to Faunia's funeral, Coleman's was stage managed to the nth degree by his family. This was to be Coleman's formal rehabilitation into the Athena College pantheon of heroes -and Coleman's children had spared no pains to get out the vote. They had even found a sacrificial lamb. PAN DOWN FROM to Herb Keeble as he mounts the pulpit. The is a beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: (quietly) My name is Herbert Keble. I am chairman of the Political Science Department - and I was among those who did not rise to Coleman's defense when he was accused of racism. Throughout this we CROSS CUT TO THE SILK PEW - where Coleman's children sit: Jeff, Mark (wearing a yarmulke) a Lisa in tears. We also see all the characters from the college we've met, from the couple who avoided Coleman outside the library, even a stoic Delphine Roux along wit Nelson Primus and his wife. And near the back Nathan Zuckerman off by himself, listening, watching.  94 95 100.

dialogues.speaker: HERB
dialogues.text: (continuing) "Coleman, I can't be with you on this." That is what I said, to my everlasting shame. Oh, I had my reasons. I thought I could help better behind the scenes. If I allied myself publicly, I told myself, I risked being labeled an Uncle Tom and thereby useless. I was wrong! I should never have said to my friend, "I can't be with you on this." I should have said, "I MUST be with you on this." I should have spoken up to say what I want to say now in the presence of his former colleagues and especially in the presence of his children: that the alleged misconduct never took place. Coleman Silk and his wife Iris were betrayed by the moral stupidity of a censorious, coercive community and I was a member of that community. We all were. Nathan looks around. People are crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The service is over, people drift away from the gravesite CLOSE ON TWO ADJOINING TOMBSTONES which read:

dialogues.speaker: IRIS SILK 1934-1998 COLEMAN SILK 1930-
dialogues.text: Nathan remains, lost in thought as people disappear aroun him. Only gradually is he aware... There's a WOMAN perhaps 62, still standing by the grave, primly holding her purse, a blank expression on her face. She is a light-skinned African American.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Keble? (she looks at him) I believe your husband's eulogy changed everything today. The woman turns to him.  95 96 101.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not Mrs. Keble. TIGHT ON NATHAN, as he slowly realizes -

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You're...Are you Coleman's sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan and Ernestine are sitting in the lounge of a quain country inn. TIGHT ON THE HAND OF A WAITER--as he serves them tea.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Lemon or milk?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Milk. (then: ) That day Walter told Coleman never to contact mother again - he froze everything forever.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Your mother obeyed Walter?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: All the Silk men from my father on down are very decisive, Mr. Zuckerman. Yes, she did. But I didn't. I'd phone Coleman on his birthday, things like that... I was trying to reach him two days ago, his seventieth birthday... the day after he was killed. (realizes) I must have spoken to one of my nephews- (she looks away for a moment then regaining her composure) I don't blame Walter; he was trying to spare my mother more heartache.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Did he succeed?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: When she died in the hospital, she was delirious. :
96 ERNESTINE (cont'd) She kept saying, "Oh nurse, get me to the train, I got a sick baby at home..." Over and over. Walter and I knew who that sick baby was.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Is Walter still alive?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. We're all a family of teachers, Mr. Zuckerman, imagine. Even Coleman's side of the family -I wish our parents had known that. And Walter was the first colored superintendant of schools in the state of New Jersey. (smiles) I guess you can tell what generation I am - I say "colored" and "Negro".

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Did you know why your brother resigned from the college? ERNESTINE . I gather he was accused of racism. (smiles sadly) That beats all, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: For using the word "spooks".

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Sounds like from what I've heard today that anything is possible nowadays. People are just getting dumber - but more opinionated. The year I retired, youngsters were telling me that for Black History Month they would only read a biography of a black BY a black. What kind of silly idea is "Black History Month" anyway? If you're going to study Charles Drew, you do him when you do "science", don't segregate him in "Black History Month", for heavens sake.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't know who Charles Drew is.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Shame on you, Mr. Zuckerman. Dr. Charles Drew discovered how to prevent blood from clotting so it could be banked. Then he was injured in a car accident and the nearest hospital would not take colored, so he bled to death. Silence as Nathan contemplates this. She looks at him -

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know what's sad, Mr. Zuckerman? Nowadays it's impossible to imagine anyone doing what my brother felt he had to do then... constructing his whole life around a lie. He could have stopped that racism charge in its tracks - I wonder if that solution even occurred to him. Tell me something, Mr. Zuckerman. Did he ever acknowledge what he'd done? To anyone? CLOSE ON NATHAN--He is silent for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. I don't think he did.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (a rueful smile) So he was Coleman until the end. Set out to do something and do it all the way. Even to the point of being buried as Jew. (sadly) Oh, Coleman... She stands; Nathan stands as well.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, It's been quite a day... THE CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM as they start towards the door

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell Walter?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Not unless he asks.  104.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: What about Coleman's children?

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: It was for Coleman to tell them; not me.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: 97 98 But you told me.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: No, you said, "You're Coleman's sister," and I admitted it. I'm not the one with something to hide.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: (continuing; she extends a hand) Thank you for your hospitality...

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: May I come and visit you in New Jersey? I'd very much like to meet Walter.

dialogues.speaker: ERNESTINE
dialogues.text: Let me think about it... And she walks out the door.

dialogues.text: Beautiful spot.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Away from all the craziness. I'm out of it. (steals another glance) Long as I can keep it secret...  106.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: True enough. Only now I know. Les glances up again, then back at his fishing line-

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You look like a man who can keep a secret. Aren't you the writer?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: What do you think about if the fish aren't biting? He doesn't answer for a moment, then -

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: I was thinking if I had a son he'd be out here with me now, fishing. That's what I was thinking when you walked out here. Thought you might have been my son.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Do you have a son?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Never married? Another pause. Then, finally, he makes a face -

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Doomed. (he jiggles the line) When I came back from Vietnam I couldn't relate to anybody. (looking around) Clean clothes, folks saying Hello, going to parties - I couldn't relate to it anymore. Used to get in my car and drive around. My buddies were afraid I was going to die in a car accident, they were-

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Were you ever in a car accident?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (smiles) Wouldn't know if I was.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You still have PTSD? Post Traumatic Stress Disorder?

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Well, I tend to isolate, don't I? What do you think I'm doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: But no more car accidents...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: There were never any accidents. Don't you listen?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: And no kids.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Nope. You?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Married?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: No more.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: So, you and me in the same boat. What kind of books you write?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I. write about people like you.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: Is that so? What's the name of one of your books?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (hesitates) The Human Stain. It's not finished.

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: When it is, I'll buy it.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I'll send you a copy. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: LES

dialogues.text: I will if you promise to read it. Les rises, putting down the fishing line and picking up t dreadful-looking corkscrew AUGER. dialogues.text: I started ice fishing after my wife left me. All you have to do is dress warm and own the right equipment - like this auger. You drill a hole through the ice. dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (continuing) Any flash down there and the fish are attracted. They're sensitive to movement. The smallest vibration can alert them - even in the dark. And it's way dark down there... that Nathan is frightened, his tone changes -

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: (continuing) If I had a son, Little Les, a son of my own, I reckon I'd be teaching him all this stuff instead of you.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: It's cold out here...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: You better believe it.  109.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: (taking a step backwards) I should be going...

dialogues.speaker: LES
dialogues.text: But you know your ice fishing now, don't you? You can put it in your book... Nathan continues backing up, still facing Les and that DR

dialogues.text: I hear you...

dialogues.text: (a beat then) And, hey, Mr. Zuckerman. ON NATHAN--He freezes.
